verses.verse: In that hour, the students came to Jesus, saying, "Who, then, is greater in the empire of the heavens?"
And when Jesus called for a young child, He stood him in the middle of them.
And He said, "Amen, I tell you, if you will not turn and become as the young children, you will not in any way go into the empire of the heavens.
So anyone who will put himself down low as this young child, this is the greater one in the empire of the heavens.
And whoever accepts one young child of this type based on My name accepts Me.

But whoever trips one of these little ones, the ones who trust in Me, it is advantageous to him that a millstone (the kind turned by a donkey) be hung on his neck and he be dropped down in the deep part of the sea.
What a tragedy it is to the world from the obstacles! You see, there is an obligation for the obstacles to come. More importantly, what a tragedy it is to that person through whom the obstacle comes!

But if your hand or your foot trips you up, chop them out, and throw them away from you. Is it nice for you to go into the life crippled or physically handicapped, or having two hands or two feet to be thrown into the fire, the one that spans all time?
And if your eye trips you up, take it out, and throw it away from you. Is it nice for you to go into the life one-eyed, or having two eyes to be thrown into the Hinnom Valley of the fire?
Look. No one should ignore one of these little ones. You see, I tell you that their angels in the heavens look through everything at the face of My Father, the One in the heavens.
You see, the Son of the Person came to rescue the lost sheep.

What does it seem to you? If it happens that a certain person has a hundred sheep and one from them wanders off, will he not leave the ninety-nine on the mountains and, after traveling away, look for the one that wandered off?
And if he happens to find it, amen, I tell you that he is happy based on it rather than based on the ninety-nine, the ones that have not wandered off.
In this way, it is not something wanted in front of your Father, the One in the heavens, that one of these little ones would be ruined.
If your brother sins in reference to you, go back and reprimand him between you and him alone. If he listens to you, you gained your brother.
But if he does not listen, take along with you one or two more so that based on the mouth of two or three witnesses every statement might be established.
If he disregards them, talk to the assembly. If he also disregards the assembly, he must be to you even as the non-Jewish person and the tax collector.
Amen, I tell you, whatever you lock up on the earth will be things that have been locked up in the heaven, and whatever you release on the earth will be things that have been released in the heaven.
Again, I tell you that if two of you on the earth agree together about every item, whatever they ask for, it will happen to them from the side of My Father, the One in the heavens.
You see, where there are two or three that have been gathered together into My name, I am there in the middle of them."
At that time, when Peter came forward to Him, he said, "Master, how many times will my brother sin in reference to me and I will forgive him, until seven times?"
Jesus says to him, "I do not say to you, until seven times, but until seventy times multiplied by seven.
Because of this, the empire of the heavens is like a person, a king, who wanted to collect on an account with his slaves.
After he began to be collecting, one was brought to him, a person with a debt of ten thousand talents (ten million dollars).
Since he did not have a way to give it back, his master gave the order for him, his wife, his children, and everything (as much as he has) to be put up for sale and for it to be given back.
So after the slave got down on the ground, he was bowing to him, saying, 'Master, be patient over me, and I will give everything back to you.'
After the master of that slave had sympathy, he dismissed him and forgave the loan to him.

But after that slave went out, he found one of his fellow slaves who owed him one hundred denarii ($5000), and when he took hold of him, he was choking him, saying, 'Give me back anything that you owe.'
So when his fellow slave got down at his feet, he was encouraging him, saying, 'Be patient over me, and I will give everything back to you.'
The slave was not wanting to. But when he went away, he threw him into jail until the time that he would give back what was owed.
When his fellow slaves saw the things that happened, they were terribly sad. And after they went, they clarified to their master all the things that happened.
At that time, after his master called for him, he says to him, 'Evil slave, I forgave you every bit of that amount owed by you since you encouraged me to.
Wasn't it necessary for you to also show forgiving kindness to your fellow slave as I also showed forgiving kindness to you?'
And after being enraged, his master turned him over to the torturers until the time that he will give back every bit of what was owed to him.
My Father, the heavenly One, will also do like this to you if each of you do not forgive his brother from your hearts of their infractions."
